repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Second Integrated Roads and
            Central Transport Corridor and Uganda - First and Second
            Phase Road Development and Roads Sector Institutional
            Support Technical Assistance Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Integrated Roads
            Project for Tanzania were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and borrower
            performance was Unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Central
            Transport Corridor Project for Tanzania were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Roads Sector Institutional
            Support Technical Assistance Project for Uganda were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the First Phase Road
            Development Project for Uganda were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was high, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Ratings
            for the Second Phase Road Development Project for Uganda
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk
            to development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: The
            road agency model has provided sufficient institutional
            capacity in low income countries such as Tanzania and Uganda
            to improve the delivery of new main roads and their
            maintenance. Supporting road funds can further enhance road
            sub-sector reform provided they are properly designed and
            adequately resourced. During road reform initiatives, the
            borrower's absorptive capacity, the degree of
            opposition to change and the time it takes to prepare and
            adopt new legislation, have often been miscalculated by the
            Bank and other development partners. The Bank thus needs to
            ensure appropriate training and skills deployment to i)
            assess and address the borrower's institutional and
            absorptive capacity limitations; ii) gauge the degree of
            resistance to change and make a plan to deal with it, and
            iii) realistically estimate the time it takes to prepare,
            adopt and apply new legislation. An annual assessment of the
            condition and traffic usage of the roads in the network
            enables the decision makers and the public to understand the
            implications of greater or lesser funding.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Road Sector Institutional Support
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Sector
            Institutional Support Technical Assistance Project for
            Uganda were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: Road Agency Formation Unit (RAFU)
            was created as a default Project Implementation Unit (PIU)
            and as a nucleus for the establishment of an autonomous road
            authority and most of its salary and operational costs were
            funded by the project. This was to mitigate the risks
            related to sustainable government financing and to ensure
            that the staff was well motivated to implement the costly
            projects. However, it took long for government to prepare a
            realistic budget to meet the requirements of Uganda National
            Road Authority (UNRA) as the extended credit continued to
            finance the salaries of RAFU. As such, this became a
            disincentive for moving rapidly toward a government financed
            road authority. The lesson is that the putting in place of a
            PIU may be a disincentive for the implementation of
            institutional reform. At project preparation, a set of good
            outcome and impact indicators were designed, but no
            framework was agreed to monitor project performance and as a
            result no effective monitoring was carried out during
            project implementation. Therefore to only design performance
            indicators may not be enough unless a comprehensive
            monitoring and assessment framework has been agreed upon
            with all stakeholders at the project design stage. The
            monitoring and assessment framework should include a time
            based action plan to carry out baseline studies, regular
            reviews of interim benchmarks, and a well coordinated
            mechanism for evaluation and reporting of the project
            performance at least biannually.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Road Sector Institutional Support
            Technical Assistance Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
While the Road Sector Institutional
            Support Technical Assistance Project will examine
            rehabilitation options to minimize the need for ongoing road
            maintenance, the environmental assessment considers the
            potential environmental effects of the project on social,
            cultural, and economic resources, in a two-volume report
            covering the Katunguru - Kasese - Fort Portal Road, and
            Kasese - Kilembe Road - Equator Road segments. Measures to
            mitigate adversity are: To reduce the effects of road
            widening, those works within road reserves, should be
            conducted after harvest period, and, for those outside road
            reserve, compensation should be granted to affected
            landowners. As a result of earthworks, borrow pits will be
            available for waste, and spoil disposal, in an effort to
            reduce hydrological damage. Noise, dust, and safety risks
            will be minimized by limiting working hours to daytime
            schedules, enforcing control measures to reduce traffic
            speed, and, securing access to pedestrians, and cyclists
            through adequate traffic signals, and temporary diversions.
            During construction, health facilities will be available
            on-site, to ensure the well-being of local workforce, and
            communities. Maintenance of drainage infrastructure will be
            pursued, to avoid potential flooding of adjacent properties.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Road Sector Institutional Support
            Technical Assistance Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
While the Road Sector Institutional
            Support Technical Assistance Project will examine
            rehabilitation options to minimize the need for ongoing road
            maintenance, the environmental assessment considers the
            potential environmental effects of the project on social,
            cultural, and economic resources, in a two-volume report
            covering the Katunguru - Kasese - Fort Portal Road, and
            Kasese - Kilembe Road - Equator Road segments. Measures to
            mitigate adversity are: To reduce the effects of road
            widening, those works within road reserves, should be
            conducted after harvest period, and, for those outside road
            reserve, compensation should be granted to affected
            landowners. As a result of earthworks, borrow pits will be
            available for waste, and spoil disposal, in an effort to
            reduce hydrological damage. Noise, dust, and safety risks
            will be minimized by limiting working hours to daytime
            schedules, enforcing control measures to reduce traffic
            speed, and, securing access to pedestrians, and cyclists
            through adequate traffic signals, and temporary diversions.
            During construction, health facilities will be available
            on-site, to ensure the well-being of local workforce, and
            communities. Maintenance of drainage infrastructure will be
            pursued, to avoid potential flooding of adjacent properties.

display_title.display_title:
Uganda - Road Sector
            Institutional Support Technical Assistance Project :
            environmental assessment (Vol. 5) : Road sector EIA guidelines
